title: 105_s779
content: The Act titled "Medicare Physician Workforce Improvement Act of 1997" is cited as such. Congress finds a critical shortage of certified geriatricians, high educational debt for training, and financial disincentives for entering geriatric medicine. Training in various medical care settings is essential for physicians providing services to elderly individuals. Training in various medical care settings is essential for physicians providing services to elderly individuals. SEC. 3. GRADUATE MEDICAL EDUCATION FUNDING. The amendment to Section 1886(h)(4) of the Social Security Act specifies that residents enrolled in a geriatric medicine or geriatric psychiatry fellowship will be counted twice for the computation of full-time-equivalent residents in a medical residency training program. The amendment limits the number of residents counted twice for full-time-equivalent residents in a medical residency program to 400 per calendar year. This amendment applies to cost reporting periods starting after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF GERIATRICIANS. A geriatric training consortium is a State, regional, or local entity developed and supported by an accredited geriatric training program. It consists of a teaching hospital, a skilled nursing facility, and an ambulatory care or community-based facility for the training of residents in postgraduate programs. The curr_chunk discusses formal postgraduate training programs in geriatric medicine or geriatric psychiatry, as well as the provision of appropriate training experiences for residents in primary care disciplines. Primary care is defined as family medicine, general internal medicine, general pediatrics, preventive medicine, geriatric medicine, and osteopathic general practice. The terms "resident" and "Secretary" are also defined. The Secretary will establish 5 demonstration projects through geriatric training consortia to increase certified geriatricians trained to provide services to beneficiaries under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Payments will be made for indirect and direct graduate medical education costs related to training residents. Any geriatric training consortium can apply to conduct a demonstration project. The Secretary may waive compliance with certain requirements of the Social Security Act for demonstration projects. An annual report evaluating project effectiveness will be submitted to Congress with any legislative recommendations deemed appropriate. The Secretary may waive Social Security Act requirements for demonstration projects. An annual report will evaluate project effectiveness and include recommendations on continuation or replication. Projects will last up to 5 years, with potential termination for non-compliance. Funding will be transferred from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. The Secretary may waive Social Security Act requirements for demonstration projects, with funding transferred from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund. The total amount paid to a project in a year shall not exceed $1,000,000. The subparagraph specifies the amount of funding for geriatric fellows in a training consortium, based on Medicare payments received by the hospital. The funding for the demonstration project is determined when the Secretary appropriates the funds for that year.
